conclusion: To determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B, we need to analyze their velocity-time (v-t) graphs and calculate the areas under the curves, which represent the displacement of each car.
Car A: Constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 0 to t = 30 s.
Car B: Starts from rest and accelerates linearly to 40 m/s at t = 20 s, then maintains 40 m/s from t = 20 s to t = 30 s.

premise: Car A travels at a constant velocity of 40 m/s.
conclusion: Displacement of Car A from t = 0 to t = 30 s: 40 m/s × 30 s = 1200 m

premise: Car B accelerates from 0 to 40 m/s over 20 seconds.
conclusion: The area under the velocity-time graph for Car B from t = 0 to t = 20 s is a triangle: 1/2 × 20 s × 40 m/s = 400 m

premise: Car B travels at a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 20 s to t = 30 s.
Total displacement of Car B from t = 0 to t = 30 s.
conclusion: Total Displacement of Car B = 400 m + 400 m = 800 m

premise: At t = 30 s, both cars are side by side, so their displacements are equal.
conclusion: The difference in displacement between Car A and Car B at any time t is given by the difference in the areas under their respective v-t graphs.

premise: The maximum distance occurs when the difference in displacement is greatest.
conclusion: At t = 20 s, Car A has traveled: Displacement of Car A = 40 m/s × 20 s = 800 m

premise: At t = 20 s, Car B has traveled: Displacement of Car B = 400 m
conclusion: The maximum distance between Car A and Car B is: Maximum Distance = 800 m - 400 m = 400 m
